title: THE MIDNIGHT APOTHECARY
subtitle: A Deadly Draught Claims a Prominent Physician
teaser: The esteemed Dr. Whitmore was found dead in his bed-chamber, victim of what appears to be his own sleeping draught—but the circumstances suggest a more sinister hand at work. His young assistant stands accused, yet the evidence is far from conclusive.
briefing:
═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

                    ❧ POISONING MOST FOUL ❧
                        
Dr. JAMES WHITMORE, esteemed physician and pillar of the community, 
was discovered lifeless in his study yesterday morning. The good 
doctor had retired early, complaining of a headache, and requested 
a sleeping draught from the local apothecary.

By dawn, he was dead. The constabulary have arrested Mr. THOMAS 
GREENE, the young apothecary's assistant who prepared the fatal 
mixture, charging him with murder by poison.

Yet whispers circulate through the district that all is not as it 
seems. Dr. Whitmore had enemies—patients who blamed him for failed 
treatments, colleagues jealous of his reputation, and rumors of a 
scandal involving the doctor's young wife.

Was this truly a case of negligent poisoning, or did someone 
deliberately tamper with the doctor's medicine?

The truth awaits a discerning investigator.

characters.name: Thomas Greene
characters.description: A nervous young man barely out of his apprenticeship, with ink-stained fingers and dark circles under his eyes. Thomas Greene speaks quickly, as if afraid he might not finish his sentence before being dragged away in irons.
characters.initialDialogue:
"I swear upon my mother's grave, I followed the prescription exactly! Laudanum, fifteen drops. Valerian root. Nothing more!"

Thomas wrings his hands, pacing behind the counter of the shop.

"The master, Mr. Pemberton, he trusts me with routine preparations. I've made hundreds of sleeping draughts without incident!"

He pauses, lowering his voice.

"But there was something strange that night. Someone came in after closing, when I was cleaning up. I heard voices in the back—Mr. Pemberton speaking with someone. I didn't see who."

"The next morning, my prepared bottles had been moved. I thought nothing of it at the time..."

conditionalDialogue.clue_moved_bottles:
"Yes! That's exactly what I mean! The bottles were in a different order than I left them!"

Thomas becomes animated, hope flickering in his eyes.

"I always arrange them alphabetically—it's my system. But in the morning, the doctor's bottle was at the front, not where I placed it."

"Someone tampered with them. It wasn't me!"
conditionalDialogue.clue_insurance:
"Dr. Whitmore's wife? She came to the shop that very afternoon!"

Thomas's eyes widen.

"She was asking about poisons—said she had a rat problem. Mr. Pemberton sold her arsenic. I remember because she paid in cash, which is unusual for the doctor's household."

"You don't think...?"

characters.name: Harold Pemberton
characters.description: A portly man with spectacles perched on a bulbous nose, Mr. Pemberton exudes an air of professional dignity somewhat undermined by the sweat beading on his forehead.
characters.initialDialogue:
"A terrible business, terrible! Poor Thomas is a capable lad, but mistakes happen. The pressure of the work, you understand."

Mr. Pemberton adjusts his spectacles nervously.

"Dr. Whitmore was a valued customer. I prepared his medicines personally for years. But that night, I was... indisposed. I left Thomas to handle the closing."

"The boy must have confused the dosages. An honest error, but a fatal one."

conditionalDialogue.clue_late_visitor:
Mr. Pemberton's composure cracks.

"A visitor? I... I don't recall any..."

He mops his brow with a handkerchief.

"Very well. Yes, someone came after hours. A lady, heavily veiled. She had a private matter to discuss—feminine troubles, you understand. I am bound by professional discretion."

"It had nothing to do with Dr. Whitmore's medicine. Nothing at all!"

characters.name: Mary Whitmore
characters.description: A strikingly beautiful woman in her late twenties, far younger than her deceased husband. Mrs. Whitmore wears black crepe, but her eyes are dry and her demeanor is remarkably composed for a new widow.
characters.initialDialogue:
"My husband was a great man. The community has lost a healer of exceptional skill."

Mrs. Whitmore sits rigidly in the parlor, hands folded in her lap.

"Our marriage was... conventional. He provided security. I provided companionship. We understood each other."

She glances toward the study door.

"James often worked late. His sleeping draughts were a necessity—his mind would not quiet without them. That the medicine meant to give him peace should be his end... it is cruelly ironic."

conditionalDialogue.clue_insurance:
Mrs. Whitmore's composure finally wavers.

"The insurance policy? Yes, I am aware of it. James took it out years ago, when his practice was struggling."

She rises, moving to the window.

"You think me a monster. A young wife who married for money and murdered for inheritance. How... unoriginal."

"I did not kill my husband. But I know who did."

She turns, her eyes hard.

"Ask Mr. Pemberton about his debts. Ask him who forgave those debts in exchange for a small favor."

characters.name: Samuel Doyle
characters.description: A barrel-chested man with arms like ham hocks, Samuel Doyle has run this establishment for twenty years and knows everyone's business whether they wish it or not.
characters.initialDialogue:
"Dr. Whitmore? Aye, he'd come in of an evening. Brandy for the digestion, he'd say."

The publican polishes a glass with a rag of questionable cleanliness.

"Can't say I'm surprised someone did him in. Man had more enemies than friends, for all his fancy reputation."

"There was that business with Mrs. Collins—said his treatment killed her husband. And Dr. Hartley at the hospital fair hated him. Professional jealousy, they say."

conditionalDialogue.clue_argument:
"The argument? Oh, you heard about that?"

Samuel leans closer.

"Two nights before the poisoning, the apothecary—Pemberton—came in looking like death himself. He was muttering about debts, about being ruined."

"Then a well-dressed fellow joined him. Couldn't hear everything, but I caught 'make it look natural' and 'no one will suspect the assistant.'"

"Pemberton left looking relieved. The other man paid for his drinks with a sovereign. Who carries sovereigns to a tavern?"

clues.title: The Rearranged Medicines
clues.discoveryText:
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
                        ❧ TESTIMONY RECORDED ❧
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Thomas Greene describes a disturbing observation:

"The bottles were moved. I always arrange them alphabetically, 
but in the morning, Dr. Whitmore's sleeping draught was at the 
front of the shelf, not in its proper place."

This suggests someone accessed the medicines after Thomas 
prepared them and before they were delivered.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
clues.notebookSummary: Thomas noticed the medicine bottles had been rearranged overnight—someone accessed them after he finished preparing them.

clues.title: The Veiled Lady
clues.discoveryText:
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
                        ❧ SUSPICIOUS VISITOR ❧
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Under pressure, Mr. Pemberton admits:

"Yes, a woman came after closing hours. She was heavily veiled 
and insisted on privacy. I... I cannot reveal her identity."

His nervous demeanor suggests there is more to this visit than 
he is willing to admit. The timing is suspicious—the same night 
the fatal draught was prepared.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
clues.notebookSummary: A veiled woman visited the apothecary after hours on the night the poison was prepared. Pemberton refuses to identify her.

clues.title: The Overheard Plot
clues.discoveryText:
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
                        ❧ DAMNING EVIDENCE ❧
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

The publican recounts a conversation he overheard:

"Pemberton was here two nights before the death, looking 
terrified. A well-dressed man joined him—couldn't see his 
face clearly."

"I heard them say 'make it look natural' and 'no one will 
suspect the assistant.' Pemberton left looking relieved."

This strongly suggests Pemberton was recruited to tamper with 
the medicine, using his assistant as a scapegoat.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
clues.notebookSummary: The publican overheard Pemberton discussing a plot with an unknown man: 'make it look natural' and 'no one will suspect the assistant.' PEMBERTON WAS INVOLVED.

clues.title: The Insurance Policy
clues.notebookSummary: Dr. Whitmore took out a £10,000 life insurance policy just three months ago. His wife is the sole beneficiary.

clues.title: The Arsenic Sale
clues.discoveryText:
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
                        ❧ POISON REGISTER ❧
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Examining the poison register (required by law for all toxic 
substance sales), you find an entry:

    DATE: Two days before death
    PURCHASER: Mrs. M. Whitmore
    SUBSTANCE: Arsenic (white powder), 2 drams
    PURPOSE STATED: Vermin control
    PAYMENT: Cash

The handwriting is Pemberton's. Cash payment is unusual for a 
regular customer with an account.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
clues.notebookSummary: Mrs. Whitmore purchased arsenic from the apothecary two days before her husband's death, paying cash instead of using the family account.

solution.motive:
DEBT AND COERCION

Harold Pemberton, the master apothecary, was drowning in gambling 
debts. He was approached by an unknown party (likely connected to 
Mrs. Whitmore or another interested party) who offered to forgive 
his debts in exchange for tampering with Dr. Whitmore's medicine.

Pemberton added poison to the sleeping draught after Thomas Greene 
prepared it, knowing the young assistant would be blamed for any 
"error" in the preparation.
solution.method:
After Thomas Greene prepared the standard sleeping draught, 
Pemberton returned to the shop that night and added a lethal dose 
of arsenic to the mixture. He rearranged the bottles in his haste, 
which Thomas noticed the following morning.

The murder was meant to look like an accidental overdose by an 
inexperienced assistant, with Thomas taking the blame.
